title: The Latest Remcos RAT Driven By Phishing Campaign

meta.title: The Latest Remcos RAT Driven By Phishing Campaign

sentences.html: By

sentences.text: Xiaopeng Zhang
sentences.html: Xiaopeng Zhang

sentences.text: FortiGuard Labs Research
sentences.html: FortiGuard Labs Research

chapters.title: The Latest Remcos RAT Driven By Phishing Campaign

sentences.text: Affected platforms: Microsoft Windows<crlf>Impacted parties: Microsoft Windows Users<crlf>Impact: Controls victims device and collects sensitive information<crlf>Severity level: Critical
sentences.html: Affected platforms: Microsoft Windows Impacted parties: Microsoft Windows Users Impact: Controls victim’s device and collects sensitive information Severity level: Critical

sentences.text: Remcos RAT (Remote Access Trojan) was originally designed as a professional tool to remotely control computers. Remcos RAT is recognized as a malware family because it has been abused by hackers to secretly control victims devices since its first version was published on July 21, 2016. Remcos RAT is commercial software that is sold online.
sentences.html: Remcos RAT (Remote Access Trojan) was originally designed as a professional tool to remotely control computers. Remcos RAT is recognized as a malware family because it has been abused by hackers to secretly control victims’ devices since its first version was published on July 21, 2016. Remcos RAT is commercial software that is sold online.

sentences.text: Figure 1: Example of Remcos RAT being sold online
sentences.html: Figure 1: Example of Remcos RAT being sold online

sentences.text: On this webpage, it provides two versions: professional edition (with all features included) and free edition (with restricted features).
sentences.html: On this webpage, it provides two versions: professional edition (with all features included) and free edition (with restricted features).

sentences.text: This analysis is based on Remcos RAT being used by hackers to control victims devices delivered by a phishing campaign, which was caught by Fortinets FortiGuard Labs recently.
sentences.html: This analysis is based on Remcos RAT being used by hackers to control victims’ devices delivered by a phishing campaign, which was caught by Fortinet’s FortiGuard Labs recently.

sentences.text: In this analysis, you will learn:
sentences.html: In this analysis, you will learn:

sentences.text: How the phishing campaign delivers Remcos RAT onto the victims device<crlf>How Remcos executes on the device<crlf>What sensitive information it could steal from a victim<crlf>How Remcos connects to its C2 server<crlf>What commands this Remcos provides to control the victims device
sentences.html:
• How the phishing campaign delivers Remcos RAT onto the victim’s device
  • How Remcos executes on the device
  • What sensitive information it could steal from a victim
  • How Remcos connects to its C2 server
  • What commands this Remcos provides to control the victim’s device

sentences.text: Figure 2: Screenshot of the phishing email content
sentences.html: Figure 2: Screenshot of the phishing email content

sentences.text: As you can see from the email content shown in Figure 2, the hacker disguised the phishing email as a payment notification from a trusted bank and asked the recipient to open the attached Excel file that is protected by a password.
sentences.html: As you can see from the email content shown in Figure 2, the hacker disguised the phishing email as a payment notification from a trusted bank and asked the recipient to open the attached Excel file that is protected by a password.

chapters.title: Excel File Leads to Download of Remcos via VBS and PowerShell

sentences.text: Once the attached Excel document is opened in the Excel program, it asks for a password to view the document, which has already been provided in the email. It then shows the document in the Excel program like Figure 3. Because the file contains Macro code, it shows a yellow security warning bar to warn the victim of the danger.
sentences.html: Once the attached Excel document is opened in the Excel program, it asks for a password to view the document, which has already been provided in the email. It then shows the document in the Excel program like Figure 3. Because the file contains Macro code, it shows a yellow security warning bar to warn the victim of the danger.

sentences.text: Figure 3: Screen shown when the Excel document is opened in the Excel program
sentences.html: Figure 3: Screen shown when the Excel document is opened in the Excel program

sentences.text: The file message lures the victim into clicking the Enable Content button to bypass the warning and execute the malicious macro code.
sentences.html: The file message lures the victim into clicking the Enable Content button to bypass the warning and execute the malicious macro code.

sentences.text: The macro has a function called Wookbook_Active() that is called automatically when it opens. Its task is to extract VBS code from the cells into a file %AppData%\HobYQ.vbs and then execute it.
sentences.html: The macro has a function called “Wookbook_Active()” that is called automatically when it opens. Its task is to extract VBS code from the cells into a file “%AppData%\HobYQ.vbs” and then execute it.

sentences.text: To protect the Remcos payload file, it uses a super sophisticated way to download it. In this way, it executes both VBS and PowerShell script codes.
sentences.html: To protect the Remcos payload file, it uses a super sophisticated way to download it. In this way, it executes both VBS and PowerShell script codes.

sentences.text: HobYQ.vbs runs a segment of dynamically spliced PowerShell code to download another VBS file (flip.vbs) from the attackers server and run it. Next, flip.vbs continues to download a file (called mem.txt) from the server, which is a piece of encoded VBS code that will be executed later in flip.vbs to download the final file from the same server, which is called faze.jpg. In Figure 4, it shows the captured traffic for the three downloaded files, flip.vbs, mem.txt, and faze.jpg.
sentences.html: “HobYQ.vbs” runs a segment of dynamically spliced PowerShell code to download another VBS file (“flip.vbs”) from the attacker’s server and run it. Next, “flip.vbs” continues to download a file (called “mem.txt”) from the server, which is a piece of encoded VBS code that will be executed later in “flip.vbs” to download the final file from the same server, which is called “faze.jpg”. In Figure 4, it shows the captured traffic for the three downloaded files, “flip.vbs,” “mem.txt,” and “faze.jpg.”

sentences.text: Figure 4: HobYQ.vbs leads to downloading three files
sentences.html: Figure 4: “HobYQ.vbs” leads to downloading three files

sentences.text: The bottom of Figure 4 shows part of the response packet of faze.jpg. Of course, it is not image file, but an obfuscated PowerShell code file. There are three pieces of encoded data defined in three array variables, which have been simplified in Figure 5 in three red boxes. The PowerShell code that is carried in faze.jpg is executed by flip.vbs.
sentences.html: The bottom of Figure 4 shows part of the response packet of “faze.jpg”. Of course, it is not image file, but an obfuscated PowerShell code file. There are three pieces of encoded data defined in three array variables, which have been simplified in Figure 5 in three red boxes. The PowerShell code that is carried in “faze.jpg” is executed by “flip.vbs”.

sentences.text: Figure 5: The simplified PowerShell code of faze.jpg
sentences.html: Figure 5: The simplified PowerShell code of “faze.jpg”

sentences.text: Let me then explain how the PowerShell code works here.
sentences.html: Let me then explain how the PowerShell code works here.

sentences.text: The values for the two variables, $MNB and $IRjR, are both encoded GZIP compression payloads (they start with 1F 8B). After decompression, $MNB is .Net Framework Dll file and $IRjR is the Remcos payload file.
sentences.html: The values for the two variables, $MNB and $IRjR, are both encoded GZIP compression payloads (they start with “1F 8B…”). After decompression, $MNB is .Net Framework Dll file and $IRjR is the Remcos payload file.

sentences.text: The binary value that is set to variable $qgRf is a dynamic method called tMCfkSD() for decompression.
sentences.html: The binary value that is set to variable “$qgRf” is a dynamic method called tMCfkSD() for decompression.

sentences.text: It calls tMCfkSD() to decompress the .Net Dll from $MNB into $byUsWxe. At last, it loads the .Net Dll into current PowerShell execution environment by calling Load and the function Black() from class toooyou is called with RegAsm.exe and compressed Remcos Payload ($IRjR).
sentences.html: It calls tMCfkSD() to decompress the .Net Dll from $MNB into $byUsWxe. At last, it loads the .Net Dll into current PowerShell execution environment by calling “Load” and the function “Black()” from class “toooyou” is called with “RegAsm.exe” and compressed Remcos Payload ($IRjR).

chapters.title: .Net Framework Dll File Performs Process Hollowing

sentences.text: Figure 6: Break on .Net Dll toooyou.Black()
sentences.html: Figure 6: Break on .Net Dll toooyou.Black()

sentences.text: The .Net Dll is named GC.dll as you can see in Figure 6. The two passed parameters are shown in Locals. Its code is obfuscated. According to my analysis, it first dynamically extracts another Dll from its resource section named lime.dll. Next, it decompresses the Remcos payload, which will be passed to a function called "k78er0sdfffff.o70sdaf45gfg(System.String, Byte[])" that is from lime.dll at the time the function is called. Actually, this Dll is used to perform the process hollowing that is injecting the Remcos payload into a newly-created RegAsm.exe process. Once the function (k78er0sdfffff.o70sdaf45gfg()) is invoked, it finds RegAsm.exe from below locations on the victims device. In case that it fails to find the file, it exits from PowerShell without running the Remcos.
sentences.html: The .Net Dll is named GC.dll as you can see in Figure 6. The two passed parameters are shown in “Locals”. Its code is obfuscated. According to my analysis, it first dynamically extracts another Dll from its resource section named lime.dll. Next, it decompresses the Remcos payload, which will be passed to a function called "k78er0sdfffff.o70sdaf45gfg(System.String, Byte[])" that is from lime.dll at the time the function is called. Actually, this Dll is used to perform the process hollowing that is injecting the Remcos payload into a newly-created “RegAsm.exe” process. Once the function (k78er0sdfffff.o70sdaf45gfg()) is invoked, it finds “RegAsm.exe” from below locations on the victim’s device. In case that it fails to find the file, it exits from PowerShell without running the Remcos.

sentences.text: The hardcoded location list:
sentences.html: The hardcoded location list:

sentences.text: array[<Module>.C1790263187] = "C:\\WINDOWS\\syswow64\\";<crlf>array[<Module>.C2710025604] = "C:\\WINDOWS\\system32\\";<crlf>array[<Module>.C3326009313] = "C:\\WINDOWS\\";<crlf>array[<Module>.C931285936] = "C:\\WINDOWS\\syswow64\\WindowsPowerShell\\v1.0\\";<crlf>array[<Module>.const_4] = "C:\\WINDOWS\\system32\\WindowsPowerShell\\v1.0\\";<crlf>array[<Module>.C3873335087] = "C:\\Windows\\Microsoft.NET\\Framework\\v4.0.30319\\";
sentences.html: array[<Module>.C1790263187] = "C:\\WINDOWS\\syswow64\\"; array[<Module>.C2710025604] = "C:\\WINDOWS\\system32\\"; array[<Module>.C3326009313] = "C:\\WINDOWS\\"; array[<Module>.C931285936] = "C:\\WINDOWS\\syswow64\\WindowsPowerShell\\v1.0\\"; array[<Module>.const_4] = "C:\\WINDOWS\\system32\\WindowsPowerShell\\v1.0\\"; array[<Module>.C3873335087] = "C:\\Windows\\Microsoft.NET\\Framework\\v4.0.30319\\";

sentences.text: In my testing environment, it has this file at "C:\Windows\\Microsoft.NET\Framework\v4.0.30319\RegAsm.exe".
sentences.html: In my testing environment, it has this file at "C:\Windows\\Microsoft.NET\Framework\v4.0.30319\RegAsm.exe".

sentences.text: As you may know, it needs to call several APIs to finish the process hollowing, which are: CreateProcess() with CREATE_SUSPENDED flag, WriteProcessMemory(), GetThreadContext(), SetThreadContext() and so on. As shown in Figure 7, it is about to call API CreateProcessA() to create a suspended RegAsm.exe process from Lime.dll.
sentences.html: As you may know, it needs to call several APIs to finish the process hollowing, which are: CreateProcess() with CREATE_SUSPENDED flag, WriteProcessMemory(), GetThreadContext(), SetThreadContext() and so on. As shown in Figure 7, it is about to call API CreateProcessA() to create a suspended RegAsm.exe process from Lime.dll.

sentences.text: Figure 7: Call CreateProcessA() with CREATE_SUSPENDED flag
sentences.html: Figure 7: Call CreateProcessA() with CREATE_SUSPENDED flag

sentences.text: When the Remcos payload is injected and deployed onto the RegAsm.exe, API ResumeThread() will be called to have RegAsm.exe resume to run the Remcos RAT on the victims device.
sentences.html: When the Remcos payload is injected and deployed onto the RegAsm.exe, API ResumeThread() will be called to have RegAsm.exe resume to run the Remcos RAT on the victim’s device.

sentences.text: Per my analysis, Remcos was written in C++ language with templates. What we already captured is the latest version, 3.4.0 Pro, which was published on February 10, 2022. I dissected the Remcos payload file from this section to learn how it controls the victims device.
sentences.html: Per my analysis, Remcos was written in C++ language with templates. What we already captured is the latest version, 3.4.0 Pro, which was published on February 10, 2022. I dissected the Remcos payload file from this section to learn how it controls the victim’s device.

sentences.text: From the analysis of its previous versions in the past years, Remcos used RC4 encryption to encrypt or decrypt both the local data and the traffic data between Remcos and C2 servers. From the version 3.0.0 Pro on, it has changed the encryption algorithm to AES-128 bit for encrypting or decrypting the traffic data. Therefore, it is now using both encryption algorithms, RC4 for local data and AES for traffic data in this variant.
sentences.html: From the analysis of its previous versions in the past years, Remcos used RC4 encryption to encrypt or decrypt both the local data and the traffic data between Remcos and C2 servers. From the version 3.0.0 Pro on, it has changed the encryption algorithm to AES-128 bit for encrypting or decrypting the traffic data. Therefore, it is now using both encryption algorithms, RC4 for local data and AES for traffic data in this variant.

sentences.text: Figure 8: Remcos configuration block encrypted in SETTINGS resource
sentences.html: Figure 8: Remcos configuration block encrypted in “SETTINGS” resource

sentences.text: Every Remcos contains an RC4 encrypted configuration block in its PE resource section, named SETTINGS as shown in Figure 8, where the first byte B1 is the size of the following RC4 key that is in a red box and the rest data is the encrypted Remcos configuration block.
sentences.html: Every Remcos contains an RC4 encrypted configuration block in its PE resource section, named “SETTINGS” as shown in Figure 8, where the first byte “B1” is the size of the following RC4 key that is in a red box and the rest data is the encrypted Remcos configuration block.

sentences.text: The first thing Remcos does is to decrypt the configuration block, which will be referred to throughout Remcos lifetime. It contains but not limited to the C2s server information, Remcos assigned name for attacker to recognize the victim, Remcos sub-key name in registry, the name of log file for recording victims keylogger and clipboard data, many flags telling Remcos how to start its features in the victims device, as well as the authentication data used to establish connection to the C2 server.
sentences.html: The first thing Remcos does is to decrypt the configuration block, which will be referred to throughout Remcos lifetime. It contains but not limited to the C2’s server information, Remcos assigned name for attacker to recognize the victim, Remcos sub-key name in registry, the name of log file for recording victim’s keylogger and clipboard data, many flags telling Remcos how to start its features in the victim’s device, as well as the authentication data used to establish connection to the C2 server.

sentences.text: The workflow of Remcos is very clear that it starts many threads to perform auto-start work according to the flags defined in the configuration block. It includes:
sentences.html: The workflow of Remcos is very clear that it starts many threads to perform auto-start work according to the flags defined in the configuration block. It includes:

sentences.text: Adding Remcos to the auto-run group in the system registry<crlf>Starting a watchdog program (Remcos daemon program)<crlf>Recording the victims audio input from an input device ( microphone)<crlf>Capturing victims screenshots at startup<crlf>Disabling UAC (User Account Control) on the victims device<crlf>And so on
sentences.html:
• Adding Remcos to the auto-run group in the system registry
  • Starting a watchdog program (Remcos’ daemon program)
  • Recording the victim’s audio input from an input device ( microphone)
  • Capturing victim’s screenshots at startup
  • Disabling UAC (User Account Control) on the victim’s device
  • And so on

sentences.text: Remcos is able to record the victims sensitive information in a log file (file name is from the configuration block) from time to time, like keyboard inputs (keylogger), data on the system clipboard, and the title of the topmost program that the victims typing in. In order to do so, it needs to set a keyboard hook by calling API SetWindowsHookExA() and starts a thread to check every 500 microseconds. Figure 9 shows the ASM code snippet of setting such hook.
sentences.html: Remcos is able to record the victim’s sensitive information in a log file (file name is from the configuration block) from time to time, like keyboard inputs (keylogger), data on the system clipboard, and the title of the topmost program that the victim’s typing in. In order to do so, it needs to set a keyboard hook by calling API SetWindowsHookExA() and starts a thread to check every 500 microseconds. Figure 9 shows the ASM code snippet of setting such hook.

sentences.text: Figure 9: Set keyboard Windows Hook
sentences.html: Figure 9: Set keyboard Windows Hook

sentences.text: Below is an example of logs.dat with what Remcos has obtained from my test environment, such as recording date and time, topmost program titles, victims idle time, and clipboard data.
sentences.html: Below is an example of “logs.dat” with what Remcos has obtained from my test environment, such as recording date and time, topmost program titles, victim’s idle time, and clipboard data.

sentences.text: Figure: 10: Example of information saved in log.dat
sentences.html: Figure: 10: Example of information saved in “log.dat”

sentences.text: The next step in the Remcos workflow is to connect to its C2 server per the information from the configuration block.
sentences.html: The next step in the Remcos workflow is to connect to its C2 server per the information from the configuration block.

sentences.text: Remcos uses TLS v1.3 protocol to communicate with the C2 server, which is implemented by itself (not using Windows APIs) on the TLS handshake and authentication as I mentioned before.
sentences.html: Remcos uses TLS v1.3 protocol to communicate with the C2 server, which is implemented by itself (not using Windows APIs) on the TLS handshake and authentication as I mentioned before.

sentences.text: Remcos then collects the basic information from the victims system and submits it in the first packet to the C2 server. The packet number for the first packet is 4BH. The packet to go through AES encryption is shown below.
sentences.html: Remcos then collects the basic information from the victim’s system and submits it in the first packet to the C2 server. The packet number for the first packet is 4BH. The packet to go through AES encryption is shown below.

sentences.text: Figure 11: 4BH packet plaintext content before AES encryption
sentences.html: Figure 11: 4BH packet plaintext content before AES encryption

sentences.text: The victims basic information is enclosed in this packet. Lets take a look at the packet structure.
sentences.html: The victim’s basic information is enclosed in this packet. Let’s take a look at the packet structure.

sentences.text: The first 24 04 FF 00 is the packet magic ID that comes from the decrypted configuration block, the subsequent dword A1 02 00 00 (21AH) is the size of following data, the next dword 4B 00 00 00 (4BH) is the packet number. The entire rest data are the collected basic information of the victims device, which includes but not limited to:
sentences.html: The first “24 04 FF 00” is the packet magic ID that comes from the decrypted configuration block, the subsequent dword “A1 02 00 00” (21AH) is the size of following data, the next dword “4B 00 00 00” (4BH) is the packet number. The entire rest data are the collected basic information of the victim’s device, which includes but not limited to:

sentences.text: Remcos assigned name Shiesty (from configuration block)<crlf>Victims user name and computer name<crlf>Windows edition information, total RAM (3757629400) in bytes<crlf>Remcos version (3.4.0 Pro)<crlf>The full path of current RegAsm.exe, the title of the currently active program (the victims using)<crlf>Victims idle time<crlf>The systems uptime<crlf>CPU information<crlf>C2 server host<crlf>Remcos payload type (EXE or DLL)
sentences.html:
• Remcos assigned name “Shiesty” (from configuration block)
  • Victim’s user name and computer name
  • Windows edition information, total RAM (3757629400) in bytes
  • Remcos version (3.4.0 Pro)
  • The full path of current RegAsm.exe, the title of the currently active program (the victim’s using)
  • Victim’s idle time
  • The system’s uptime
  • CPU information
  • C2 server host
  • Remcos payload type (EXE or DLL)

sentences.text: All above value fields are split by a separator - 7C 1E 1E 1F 7C (shown as || in string).
sentences.html: All above value fields are split by a separator - “7C 1E 1E 1F 7C” (shown as “|…|” in string).

sentences.text: As long as the C2 server receives this 4BH packet, it shows the victim in the Connection subtab, as shown in Figure 12. Since then the attacker can control the victims device by just right clicking on the item (red box) and selecting the commands they wanted.
sentences.html: As long as the C2 server receives this 4BH packet, it shows the victim in the “Connection” subtab, as shown in Figure 12. Since then the attacker can control the victim’s device by just right clicking on the item (red box) and selecting the commands they wanted.

sentences.text: Figure 12: How C2 server looks when receiving a 4BH packet
sentences.html: Figure 12: How C2 server looks when receiving a 4BH packet

sentences.text: Meanwhile, Remcos registers a callback function that parses the C2s commands and goes to an infinite loop to wait for the upcoming control commands from the attackers C2 server.
sentences.html: Meanwhile, Remcos registers a callback function that parses the C2’s commands and goes to an infinite loop to wait for the upcoming control commands from the attacker’s C2 server.

sentences.text: From the registered callback function, we learned that this Remcos variant provides 87 control commands, which have been categorized in below groups:
sentences.html: From the registered callback function, we learned that this Remcos variant provides 87 control commands, which have been categorized in below groups:

sentences.text: System: Screen Capture, File Manager, File Search, Process Manager, etc.<crlf>Surveillance: Webcam, Microphone, Keylogger, Screenlogger, etc.<crlf>Network: Proxy, Downloader, Open Webpage, etc.<crlf>Extra: Dll Loader, Logins Cleaner, Audio Player, etc.<crlf>Remcos: Reconnect, Restart, Show, Update, Close, Uninstall, etc.<crlf>Heartbeat packet
sentences.html:
• System: Screen Capture, File Manager, File Search, Process Manager, etc.
  • Surveillance: Webcam, Microphone, Keylogger, Screenlogger, etc.
  • Network: Proxy, Downloader, Open Webpage, etc.
  • Extra: Dll Loader, Logins Cleaner, Audio Player, etc.
  • Remcos: Reconnect, Restart, Show, Update, Close, Uninstall, etc.
  • Heartbeat packet

sentences.text: The C2 server sends a heartbeat packet to Remcos every 40 seconds. Once Remcos has connected to the C2 server, the heartbeat makes sure this Remcos is alive. The C2s command packet has same format. Ill take the heartbeat packet as an instance to explain, which looks like:
sentences.html: The C2 server sends a heartbeat packet to Remcos every 40 seconds. Once Remcos has connected to the C2 server, the heartbeat makes sure this Remcos is alive. The C2’s command packet has same format. I’ll take the heartbeat packet as an instance to explain, which looks like:

sentences.text: After the packet magic ID (24 04 FF 00) and packet size (0x0C), 01 00 00 00 is heartbeat command number (0x01), and rest is command data being split by 7C 1E 1E 1F 7C that are 30 (ASCII 0) and 32 30 (ASCII 20). Remcos then obtains the title of currently active window as well as a time value and sends them to the C2 server in packet number 4CH.
sentences.html: After the packet magic ID (“24 04 FF 00”) and packet size (0x0C), “01 00 00 00” is heartbeat command number (0x01), and rest is command data being split by “7C 1E 1E 1F 7C” that are 30 (ASCII “0”) and 32 30 (ASCII “20”). Remcos then obtains the title of currently active window as well as a time value and sends them to the C2 server in packet number 4CH.

sentences.text: The following is a control command list:
sentences.html: The following is a control command list:

2.2: Control the victim’s device in a remote desktop.
2.3: Manager file system on victim’s device.
2.9: Open a Task Manager similar interface.
2.10: View, Set, and Empty victim’s system clipboard.
2.12: Execute a command in the victim’s device, like Notepad.
2.13: Execute JS, VBS, and Batch on the victim’s device.
2.14: Set the victim’s desktop wallpaper with a picture.
2.15: Log off, Sleep, Hibernate, Shut down, and Restart.
2.17: Turn on the victim’s audio input device, like Microphone.
2.22: Open a URL with the victim’s default browser.
2.23: Pop up a chatting box to chat with the victim.
2.24: Pop up a message to the victim.
2.25: Download and execute a file on the victim’s device.
2.26: Execute a Dll module on the victim’s device.
2.27: Play an audio sound to the victim.
2.30: Uninstall Remcos from the victim’s device.

Name

C&C Number

Browser history

21H

Restart

Restart Remcos.

Elevate

27H

Elevate Remcos’ privileges.

sentences.text: Besides the listed control commands, Remcos also has many sub-commands to support some of the control commands in sub-connections, like Service Manager command 34H with sub-commands: 03H to stop a service, 04H to pause a service, 01H to restart a service.
sentences.html: Besides the listed control commands, Remcos also has many sub-commands to support some of the control commands in sub-connections, like Service Manager command 34H with sub-commands: 03H to stop a service, 04H to pause a service, 01H to restart a service.

sentences.text: In this analysis blog, I explained how a phishing email delivers an Excel document with malicious Macro into the victims device.
sentences.html: In this analysis blog, I explained how a phishing email delivers an Excel document with malicious Macro into the victim’s device.

sentences.text: Next, we went through how it executes multiple VBS and Powershell scripts to download the Remcos payload as well as how the Remcos payload is deployed by a .Net Dll into the RegAsm.exe process via Process Hollowing.
sentences.html: Next, we went through how it executes multiple VBS and Powershell scripts to download the Remcos payload as well as how the Remcos payload is deployed by a .Net Dll into the “RegAsm.exe” process via Process Hollowing.

sentences.text: Then, I dissected Remcoss workflow according to its code and how a configuration block is decrypted from the PE resource section. I also explained how Remcos established connection to its C2 server.
sentences.html: Then, I dissected Remcos’s workflow according to its code and how a configuration block is decrypted from the PE resource section. I also explained how Remcos established connection to its C2 server.

sentences.text: Finally, through several examples, I elaborated the structure of the control and command packets in plaintext as well as what commands Remcos is able to use to control the victims device and the control command list.
sentences.html: Finally, through several examples, I elaborated the structure of the control and command packets in plaintext as well as what commands Remcos is able to use to control the victim’s device and the control command list.

sentences.text: Fortinet customers are already protected from this malware by FortiGuards Web Filtering, Antivirus, FortiMail, FortiClient, FortiEDR services, IPS services, and CDR (Content Disarm and Reconstruction) services, as follows:
sentences.html: Fortinet customers are already protected from this malware by FortiGuard’s Web Filtering, Antivirus, FortiMail, FortiClient, FortiEDR services, IPS services, and CDR (Content Disarm and Reconstruction) services, as follows:

sentences.text: All relevant URLs have been rated as "Malicious Websites" by the FortiGuard Web Filtering service.
sentences.html: All relevant URLs have been rated as "Malicious Websites" by the FortiGuard Web Filtering service.

sentences.text: The captured Excel sample and the downloaded Remcos payload files are detected as "VBA/Remcos.REM!tr " and "W32/Rescoms.M!tr" and are blocked by the FortiGuard Antivirus service.
sentences.html: The captured Excel sample and the downloaded Remcos payload files are detected as "VBA/Remcos.REM!tr " and "W32/Rescoms.M!tr" and are blocked by the FortiGuard Antivirus service.

sentences.text: FortiEDR detects both the Excel file and Remcos payload file as malicious based on its behavior.
sentences.html: FortiEDR detects both the Excel file and Remcos payload file as malicious based on its behavior.

sentences.text: Fortinet also released IPS signature Remcos.Botnet to detect and block Remcos C&C traffic to protect our customers.
sentences.html: Fortinet also released IPS signature “Remcos.Botnet” to detect and block Remcos’ C&C traffic to protect our customers.

sentences.text: FortiGuard Content, Disarm, and Reconstruction (CDR) can protect users from this attack by enabling the following option:
sentences.html: FortiGuard Content, Disarm, and Reconstruction (CDR) can protect users from this attack by enabling the following option:

sentences.text: Enable/disable stripping of linked objects in Microsoft Office documents.
sentences.html: • Enable/disable stripping of linked objects in Microsoft Office documents.

sentences.text: In addition to these protections, Fortinet has multiple solutions designed to help train users to understand and detect phishing threats:
sentences.html: In addition to these protections, Fortinet has multiple solutions designed to help train users to understand and detect phishing threats:

sentences.text: The FortiPhish Phishing Simulation Service uses real-world simulations to help organizations test user awareness and vigilance to phishing threats and to train and reinforce proper practices when users encounter targeted phishing attacks.
sentences.html: The FortiPhish Phishing Simulation Service uses real-world simulations to help organizations test user awareness and vigilance to phishing threats and to train and reinforce proper practices when users encounter targeted phishing attacks.

sentences.text: In addition to these protections, we suggest that organizations also have their end users go through our FREE NSE training: NSE 1 Information Security Awareness. It includes a module on Internet threats that is designed to help end users learn how to identify and protect themselves from various types of phishing attacks.
sentences.html: In addition to these protections, we suggest that organizations also have their end users go through our FREE NSE training: NSE 1 – Information Security Awareness. It includes a module on Internet threats that is designed to help end users learn how to identify and protect themselves from various types of phishing attacks.
